title: Adjusting Imports of Aluminum Into the United States
summary:
The document titled "Proclamation 10895 of February 10, 2025" addresses the adjustment of aluminum imports into the United States due to national security concerns. Following an investigation by the Secretary of Commerce, it was determined that aluminum imports were threatening U.S. national security, prompting the imposition of a 10 percent tariff in 2018. However, continued high levels of imports, particularly from countries like Canada and Mexico, have necessitated a reevaluation.

Key findings include:
1. Despite the initial tariff, aluminum imports have surged, leading to decreased domestic production and smelter capacity utilization rates.
2. The global excess capacity crisis, particularly influenced by expansions in China and South America, has exacerbated the situation, with domestic producers facing unfair competition.
3. The Secretary has reported that the existing tariff is insufficient to mitigate these threats, leading to an increase in the tariff rate from 10 percent to 25 percent.
4. Existing agreements with several countries regarding aluminum imports will be terminated, and all imports from these nations will now be subject to the higher tariff.

The implications of this proclamation are significant, as it aims to bolster the domestic aluminum industry by curbing imports that undermine national security. By increasing tariffs and eliminating product exclusions, the administration seeks to ensure that U.S. aluminum producers can compete effectively, thereby enhancing national security and economic stability. The changes will take effect on March 12, 2025.
